Dr. Alex Kalynychenko: A lecturer at the University of Toronto Mississauga, Department of Geography, Geomatics and Environment, who is delivering a lecture on Spatial Analysis.
University of Toronto Mississauga: A university campus where Dr. Alex Kalynychenko is delivering a lecture on Spatial Analysis.
Spatial Analysis: A type of geographical analysis which seeks to explain patterns of human behavior and its spatial expression in terms of mathematics and geometry, that is, locational analysis.
ESRI: A company that provides geographic information system software, web GIS and geodatabase management applications. In the text, it is mentioned as the source of the lecture material and as the developer of ArcGIS Pro extensions.
Carl Steinitz: A person known for his work in the field of geodesign.
Longley et al. (2015): A source of information, likely a publication or report, from the year 2015. Longley is one of the authors.
ArcGIS Pro extensions: A set of tools provided by ESRI for various types of spatial analysis, including 3D analysis, business analysis, geostatistical analysis, image analysis, network analysis, and spatial analysis.
Machine learning: A set of data-driven algorithms and techniques that automate the prediction, classification, and clustering of data.
AI: Artificial Intelligence, a branch of computer science dealing with the simulation of intelligent behavior in computers.
Deep learning: A subset of machine learning techniques that uses artificial neural networks to learn from data.
Big data analytics: The process of examining large and varied data sets to uncover hidden patterns, unknown correlations, market trends, customer preferences and other useful information. In the text, it is mentioned in the context of tools provided by ArcGIS Pro.
ESRI 2024: A source of information, likely a publication or report, from the year 2024. ESRI is a company that specializes in Geographic Information System (GIS) software.
Modeling and scripting: A concept in programming and data analysis that involves creating representations of systems and automating tasks.
Geoprocessing framework: A set of tools and functionalities in GIS software that allows for manipulation and analysis of spatial data.
Python: A high-level programming language often used in data analysis and scripting.
ModelBuilder: A visual programming language for building geoprocessing workflows in ESRI's ArcGIS software.
Zandbergen (2024): Another source of information, likely a publication or report, from the year 2024. Zandbergen is likely the author.
Area-Based Analyses: A method of geographical analysis that involves assigning characteristics to entire areas rather than individual points.
Polygon: A plane figure that is described by a finite number of straight line segments connected to form a closed polygonal chain or polygonal circuit.
Redistricting: The process of drawing electoral district boundaries in the United States.
2010 U. S. census: A decennial count of the U.S. population conducted by the U.S. Census Bureau in 2010.
Gerrymandering: A practice that attempts to establish a political advantage for a particular party or group by manipulating district boundaries.
23rd Congressional District: A former electoral district in California, which was redrawn following the 2010 census.
24th District: A current electoral district in California, which was formed following the redistricting process after the 2010 census.
Centrality: A concept in spatial analysis that involves the measure of the 'center' or 'middle' of a set of points or locations.
Mean: A measure of central tendency calculated by adding all numbers in a set and dividing by the count of numbers in the set.
Median: A measure of central tendency that represents the middle value in a set of numbers.
Mode: A measure of central tendency that represents the most frequently occurring number in a set.
Centroid: The geometric center of a plane figure or shape.
U. S. Bureau of the Census: A government agency responsible for producing data about the American people and economy, including the decennial census.
Dispersion: A measure of how spread out a set of data is.
Standard deviation: A measure of the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values.
Variance: A statistical measurement of the spread between numbers in a data set.
RMSE: Root Mean Square Error, a measure of the differences between values predicted by a model or an estimator and the values observed.
Analysis of Surfaces: A method in spatial analysis that involves studying the properties and features of surfaces, such as slopes, aspects, and watersheds.
DEM: Digital Elevation Model, a 3D representation of a terrain's surface.
2015: The year the source material was published.
https://www.travelassociates.com/: URL of a website, possibly related to travel or geography.
Orange County DEM: Digital Elevation Model of Orange County, a tool used in GIS to represent the surface of a geographic area.
River Channels: Paths through which a river flows or used to flow.
Santa Ana River: A river in Southern California, United States, that flows from the San Bernardino Mountains to the Pacific Ocean.
Seal Beach: A coastal city located in Orange County, California, United States.
Newport Beach: A coastal city in Orange County, California, United States, where the Santa Ana River actually empties into the Pacific Ocean.
Geodesign: A design and planning method which tightly couples the creation of design proposals with impact simulations informed by geographic contexts and systems thinking.
Location-allocation problems: Problems in operations research and spatial analysis concerning the optimal placement of facilities to minimize transportation costs or service delivery costs.
p-median problem: A mathematical problem that seeks the optimal location for a specified number of facilities to minimize the sum of distances from each demand point to its nearest facility.
Coverage problem: A problem in spatial analysis that seeks to minimize the furthest distance traveled to a facility.
Hakimiâ€™s theorem: A mathematical theorem used in network analysis, which states that optimal locations are at existing nodes or demand points.
Routing problems: Problems in operations research that involve determining optimal routes, often for logistics or transportation purposes.
Shortest-path problem: A problem in graph theory that seeks the shortest possible route between two points in a network.
Traveling-salesman problem (TSP): An optimization problem in computer science and operations research which focuses on optimization. In this context, it is about finding the shortest possible route that visits each city and returns to the origin city.
Orienteering problem: A routing problem that seeks to maximize the rewards associated with visiting a selection of stops while minimizing the total distance traveled.
Sears: An American chain of department stores, in this context, it's related to a system used by its drivers for scheduling and navigation.
Hypothesis testing: A statistical method used to make inferences or draw conclusions about a larger population based on a sample of data.
Randomization tests: Statistical tests that simulate a large number of random arrangements of the data to make inferences about the population.
Santa Barbara: A city in California, United States, mentioned in relation to a sample study of vegetation cover class and elevation.
ArcGIS Pro: A powerful, single desktop GIS application, which is part of ESRI's ArcGIS platform. It's used for mapping, visualization, and analysis.

Quercus: The platform through which Quiz 4 will be administered.
Week 9&10 Spatial Analysis I&II: The materials that will be covered in Quiz 4. It refers to the content taught during the ninth and tenth weeks of the course, specifically focusing on Spatial Analysis.
Recommended readings: Additional materials suggested for study, which will be included in the coverage of Quiz 4.
